document_metadata.title: Enhanced Multi-Channel Graph Convolutional Network for Aspect Sentiment Triplet Extraction
institutions: School of Artificial Intelligence, Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications, China

base_methods.evidence_text: Motivated by CNN, GCN is an efficient variant operating on graphs (Kipf and Welling, 2017).

compared_methods.comparison_result: Our EMC-GCN significantly surpasses GTS-BERT with an average of 1.96% and 2.61% F1-score on D1 and D2, respectively
compared_methods.evidence_text: Under the F1 metric, our EMC-GCN model outperforms all pipeline, end-to-end, and MRC-based methods on two groups of datasets.

compared_methods.comparison_result: The term 'light' is challenging to identify by GTS-BERT and BMRC, yet 'easy' is predicted correctly by all methods
compared_methods.evidence_text: The term 'light' is challenging to identify by GTS-BERT and BMRC, yet 'easy' is predicted correctly by all methods due to its closer proximity to 'transport' than 'light'.

datasets_used.evidence_text: We evaluate our method on two ABSA datasets from the SemEval ABSA Challenges (Pontiki et al., 2014, 2015, 2016).

stated_contributions: a comprehensive exploitation of linguistic features
stated_novelty: Our proposed framework is EMC-GCN, which addresses Aspect and Opinion Term Co-Extraction (AOTE) and Aspect-Sentiment Pair Extraction (ASPE)
We define ten types of relations between words for the ASTE task
stated_advantages: Our EMC-GCN model consistently outperforms all baseline methods on benchmark datasets

failure_cases: The term 'light' is challenging to identify by GTS-BERT and BMRC
